DOC.HEAD: Hottest Franchises Are Fast Food, Magazine Finds
DOC.TEXT: Subway Sandwiches and Salads, a fast-growing chain of restaurants specializing in submarine sandwiches, was the top-ranked North American franchise in 1989 for the third consecutive year, according to Entrepreneur magazine. The magazine, which publishes it 11th annual franchise rankings in its January issue appearing newstands on Dec. 28, said Tuesday that eight of the top 10 franchises were in the fast-food category. ``It demonstrates the American emphasis on convenience,'' Rieva Lesonsky, editor of the Irvine, Calif.-based magazine, said in a telephone interview. Second was Domino's Pizza Inc., based in Ann Arbor, Mich., followed by McDonald's Corp. of Oak Brook, Ill.; Little Caesar's Pizza, based in Farmington Hills, Mich., and Burger King Corp., based in Miami. The magazine compiles its rankings by using a number of factors, including number of years in franchising, number of franchised versus company-owned units, startup costs and growth rate. Ms. Lesonsky said Subway, which is based in Milford, Conn., has grown to 3,610 franchised restuarants in 1989 from 1,375 in 1987. The restaurant's appeal, she said, is that it serves ``fast food, but it's healthy and Americans are a little more tuned in to health these days.'' Rounding out the top 10 are Dairy Queen, Minneapolis; Arby's Inc., Atlanta; Chem-Dry Carpet, Drapery & Upholstery Cleaning, Cameron Park, Calif.; Hardee's, Rocky Mount, N.C.; and Century 21 Real Estate Corp., Irvine, Calif.
